title: 104_s665
content: There is an increase in motor fuel taxes. The motor fuel taxes are increased as per the amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax on gasoline and diesel fuel is raised from 18.3 cents to 26.3 cents, and from 24.3 cents to 32.3 cents. Additionally, technical amendments include adjustments to various specific tax rates on fuel. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increase motor fuel taxes, raising the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel from 18.3 cents to 26.3 cents and from 24.3 cents to 32.3 cents. Various specific tax rates on fuel are also adjusted, such as increasing from 6 cents to 14 cents, 4.62 cents to 12.62 cents, and 3.42 cents to 11.42 cents. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase motor fuel taxes, with the tax on gasoline and diesel fuel raised to 26.3 cents and 32.3 cents respectively. Specific tax rates on fuel are adjusted, including an increase from 6 cents to 14 cents. The floor stocks tax of 8 cents per gallon is imposed on gasoline and diesel fuel held before October 1, 1995. The liability for the tax applies to those holding the fuel on that date. The floor stocks tax of 8 cents per gallon applies to gasoline and diesel fuel held before October 1, 1995. The tax must be paid by December 31, 1995, as prescribed by the Secretary. Gasoline and diesel fuel are considered held by a person if title has passed to them. Gasoline and diesel fuel are defined according to section 4082 of the Code. The term "diesel fuel" is defined by section 4092 of the Code. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury or their delegate. Gasoline or diesel fuel held for exempt uses are not subject to the tax imposed. No tax is imposed on gasoline or diesel fuel held in a vehicle tank. No tax is imposed on certain amounts of fuel. No tax on gasoline or diesel fuel held in limited quantities on October 1, 1995, if certain conditions are met and information is submitted to the Secretary as required. Exempt fuel for specified purposes. Exempt fuel held by any person is not considered for tax purposes if exempt under certain conditions. Controlled groups are treated as one person for tax purposes. The phrase "more than 50 percent" replaces "at least 80 percent" in certain subsections. Similar principles apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. Articles in foreign trade zones are exempt from certain provisions of the law. Articles located in foreign trade zones on tax-increase dates may be subject to taxes if certain conditions are met. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by section 4081 of the Code apply, insofar as they are not inconsistent with the provisions of this subsection. Inconsistent provisions apply to floor stock taxes imposed by section 4081. Use of resulting revenues includes increasing mass transit account by 2 cents and establishing AMTRAK Account in Highway Trust Fund. The Highway Trust Fund establishes the `AMTRAK Account' with funds from taxes under sections 4041 and 4081. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers the AMTRAK portion of these amounts to the account at a rate of 2 cents per gallon. Amounts in the AMTRAK Account are available for expenditures as provided by appropriation Acts. The Highway Trust Fund establishes the `AMTRAK Account' with funds from taxes under sections 4041 and 4081. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers the AMTRAK portion of these amounts to the account at a rate of 2 cents per gallon. Amounts in the AMTRAK Account are available for making capital or capital-related expenditures for AMTRAK before October 1, 1997, in accordance with section 24104 of title 49, United States Code. Rules similar to paragraphs (4) and (5) shall be applied. Additionally, the Interstate and Federal-Aid Highway Account is created within the Highway Trust Fund for specific purposes. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers funds to the Interstate and Federal-Aid Highway Account from taxes imposed under sections 4041 and 4081. This account is available for expenditures related to interstate and Federal-aid highways. The Interstate and Federal-Aid Highway Account is available for capital expenditures for highways until October 1, 1997. A State and Local Roads and Bridges Account is established in the Highway Trust Fund for such expenditures. A State and Local Roads and Bridges Account is established in the Highway Trust Fund for expenditures related to state and local roads and bridges. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers the state and local roads and bridges portion of appropriated amounts to this account, based on taxes imposed after September 30, 1995. Amounts in the account are used for expenditures related to state and local roads and bridges. The State and Local Roads and Bridges Account allows for capital expenditures on road and bridge projects before October 1, 1997, in accordance with the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 1995.
